title: Wednesday, 26th October, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

All Hail!

PM

Mission FCA

11:01 am
PM

PM

Thought we'd get down with the cool kids and start using picture filters

PM

And who better to start with other than Andrew Bailey

11:02 am
PM

Who is leading Mission FCA

PM

This news has been embargoed -- until now!

PM

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has today launched a consultation on its Mission, which is designed to provide a guiding set of principles around the strategic choices the FCA makes. It will inform the FCA’s strategy and day-to-day work over the coming years.

11:03 am
PM

The FCA has a large and complex remit, and finite resources with which to fulfil it. It has clear objectives set by Parliament, principally to ensure that relevant markets function well. The intention of the Mission is to provide clarity over the objectives, the methods to allow it to focus its efforts in the right places as well as explaining the reasoning behind the work the FCA does and a framework on how it chooses the tools it uses to do it.

PM

n developing the Mission, the FCA will be seeking engagement across the breadth of its stakeholders. Consultation with these groups will have a fundamental impact on the shape of the final strategy.

PM

Do we qualify as stakeholders Bryce?

11:03 am
BE

We must, I guess.

PM

Think Mr Bailey's predecessor came to believe we were holding something sharp and dangerous

PM

Andrew Bailey, FCA Chief Executive commented:

11:04 am
PM

“Establishing and embedding a clear mission for the FCA is critical to our success, both as a regulator and to UK financial services as a whole. Our Mission will set out a framework within which we prioritise our work, ensuring we focus our resources in the right places. This will improve accountability and transparency of how and why we make the choices that we do.

“The Mission will only be a success if our stakeholders engage with us through this consultation process. We want this to be a very open process. Out of it, we hope that we can set out a clear path ahead for financial conduct regulation in the UK.”

PM

I'll save you the key themes that the FCA will be consulting on

PM

We all know the FCA has an overarching strategic objective of ensuring the relevant markets function well.

11:05 am
undefined
PM

Meanwhile... tinhat ish

PM

Footsie off 62 points, but it's been lower today

11:06 am
PM

6954 currently

PM

6941 was the low

BE

Before heading into that, @Jimmy asks about the closure of Cheapside. Suspicious package, we believe.

11:06 am
PM

Ah , go on

BE

Everyone in Panmure's One New Change office on lockdown, so if you need to speak to anyone there they can't avoid your call.

BE

We'll bring you more when we have it.

11:08 am
BE

If we get it, which we probably won't. Because 999 times out of 1000, bomb scares are quite dull.

BE

Back to the market though, and yep. Down. Sterling reverse post the close yesterday is dumping on the miners.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,087, down 27 (-2.42%), High: 1,099, Low: 1,081, Volume: 1.57m
11:09 am
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 508.06, down 32.44 (-6.00%), High: 510.78, Low: 496.30, Volume: 2.52m
BE

................. which also has a production warning.

BE

2017 guidance cut, but 2016 also looking risky.

11:10 am
BE

Citi incoming.

BE

Market's key focus would be on 2017 guidance where copper production of 685-720kt is below 1H16 745kt indication and Citi at 752kt. less than $900m 2017 capex guidance is in-line with Citi at $893m but well above Bloomberg consensus at $753m. 2016 revised capex guidance of less than $900m is better than ~$1bn indication at 1H16 results (Citi ~$1bn). 2016 volume guidance is held at 710-740kt (Citi 712kt) but C1 is lowered by 5c to 125c/lb vs. Citi 123c/lb.

BE

Implications

2016 volume guidance looks a bit stretched after 3Q 16 volumes not picking up to expectations. This could lower consensus 2016 EPS in low single digit %. 2017 consensus EPS could decline in double digit % and cash flows would decline more than earnings on higher capex guidance. Shares could still face strong negative reaction on today's release despite already high short base.

11:11 am
BE

And Morgan Stanley.

BE

Antofagasta's Q3 production and sales came in within 2% of
our forecasts, net cash costs were 9% lower on better grades
and higher by-product sales. Nonetheless, FY17 volume
guidance disappointed by 6% and capex likely to be
~US$100mn higher (again). We stay UW.

BE

Q3 production and sales were broadly in-line, FY16 guidance unsurprising.
Antofagasta's Q3 2016 copper production and sales (incl. zaldivar) came in at
181kt and 182kt, respectively vs MSe at ~179kt (1% beat) and ~185kt (1% miss),
respectively. Sales volumes were positively impacted by inventory normalization
at Centinela Concentrates but offset by inventory build at Los Pelambres. FY16
production is now expected to be at the lower end of the guidance (710-740kt)
but this should not come as a surprise given low run-rates YTD (MSe at 688kt).
2017 guidance disappointed, on production and capex. The company is targeting
total copper production of 685-720kt in 2017, 6% below our forecast (744kt
MSe) at the midpoint. No individual mine guidance has been provided but the
lower guidance is likely to be explained by lower grades at Centinela and weak
throughput at Los Pelambres. Moreover, the company is guiding for a cumulative
capex of US$1.8bn during 2016-2017. This compares to a current cumulative
guidance of US$1.7-1.75bn (US$1.0bn in FY16 and US$0.7-0.75bn in FY17 as per
comments during H1 results). We see 5-10% upside risks to our FY17 capex
forecasts.

11:11 am
BE

Key highlights at the individual operation level: (1) production at Los Pelambres
was 3% lower vs MSe of ~90kt due to lower throughput and recovery. (3)
Production at Centinela (both concentrates and cathodes) surprised to the
upside (62kt vs MSe 58kt) as both throughput and grades have exceeded our
expectations. (3) Antucoya ramp-up is on target with the mine producing 19.4kt
(78kt annualized) of copper cathode vs MSe at ~17kt. (4) Zaldivar disappointed
with cathode output missing our forecast by 17% as lower throughput more than
offset the lift in grades. Total by-production production was mixed with strong
gold output of 70koz (~61koz on MSe) and weak molybdenum production at
1.9kt (MSe at 2.0kt).
Q3 cost performance was robust, FY16 guidance improved. Group gross cash
cost (incl. Zaldivar) came in at US$1.54/lb vs our estimate of US$1.61/lb while net
cash cost (after accounting for sales of gold, silver, and molybdenum by-
products) beat our estimate by 9% and came in at US$1.18/lb. The beat can be
explained by the higher by-product sales vs our estimates. FY16 cash cost
guidance has been reduced from US$1.30/lb to US$1.25/lb (MSe at US$1.29/lb).

BE

Provisional pricing adjustment better, implied EBITDA constitutes 5-10% upside
risks to FY16. Provisional pricing came in at US$+4.4mn vs our estimate at US$-
6.5mn for copper. Based on reported sales volumes, realized prices, and cash
costs during Q3, we calculate an implied EBITDA of c.US$360mn from the mining
operations as compared to our forecast of US$307mn on a like for like basis
(assuming US$-28mn in exploration and other central costs). This would imply
~US$50mn upside to our FY16 EBITDA estimates (+5%).
Stretched valuation, rising capital intensity keep us UW. Against the backdrop of
falling grades, rising rock hardness, and a consequent rise in cash costs, we worry
that Antofagasta's extensive capex programme will raise ND/EBITDA rise to 4.4x
by 2021e on current prices. Elevated financial leverage may result in limited
ability to buy assets if opportunities arise and a low likelihood of additional
capital returns. Valuation is unexciting in our view with 2016e spot EV/EBITDA of
8.4x; shares are pricing in a copper price of c.US$2.8/lb in 2016 real terms.

BE

Anto short of about 20% of free float, by memory.

11:12 am
undefined
BE

Right, just quickly............

BE

Ben's causing trouble again.

11:13 am
BE

https://betaville....tter-price-agreed/

BE

It's a pretty simple tale: Walt Disney Co is said to be closing in on a multi-billion dollar takeover of micro blogging site Twitter after both companies agreed on takeout price late last week.

PM

hmm

11:14 am
BE

For what it's worth, we heard exactly the same tale earlier in the week.

BE

And spent a long time chasing it. Wasted most of yesterday, in fact.

BE

And we don't think it's right.

11:14 am
BE

In fact, we're fairly confident it's not.

PM

Tell you who has had some terrific stuff on Twitter -- John Hempton

BE

Go on.

11:15 am
PM

http://brontecapit...ad-twitter-is.html

PM

Going into the detail on how costs have exploded there

PM

He reckons it's ripe for a PE buyout

11:15 am
BE

........ possibly.

PM

Needs someone tough to sack a lot of people there

BE

Also true, probably.

11:16 am
PM

Reckons it doesnt make sense for an industry buyer -- they wouldn't yield the axe properly

PM

Costs exploded from 500m to $2.5bn, revenue less so

PM

But read Hempton

11:17 am
BE

We've talked quite a lot about Twitter's strategy in the past. There's logic to putting it into a broadcaster that produces short stuff, like sports highlights and such, because it's turning into a fairly good blipvert screening platform.

BE

But people familiar with stuff have said that Disney backed off the idea of buying Twitter because it didn't match the wholesome brand.

BE

And the most recent information we have is that nothing's changed since then.

11:19 am
BE

Quick bit of sellside from Loop Capital Markets ahead of results, which they think will be rubbish.

BE

Yesterday Bloomberg reported that Twitter was in the process of laying
off approximately 8% of its workforce, or about 300 people. It cut a similar percentage
of its workforce a year ago when co-founder Jack Dorsey assumed the CEO role. With
a headcount of 3,860 as of end of Q216, it implies annualized revenues per employee of
$624k for Twitter. This compares to larger rivals Facebook (FB:$133.28-Buy) and Alphabet
(GOOGL:$835.74-NR), which have annualized revenues per employee of $1.8 million
and $1.1 million, respectively, based on Q216 figures. In addition, Twitter's stock-based
compensation as a percentage of revenues was 28% in Q2, compared to 12.5% and 7% for
Facebook and Alphabet, respectively, for the same period. With revenue growth stalling at
an estimated 6% YoY in Q2, Twitter has not grown its business into its headcount. It has
also relied heavily on stock to compensate employees, which is problematic considering the
stock is down 22% YTD and down around 50% since Mr. Dorsey was appointed interim
CEO in July 2015.

BE

• Earnings upside or sale of the company unlikely right now. With the layoffs looming,
we do not believe Twitter is in a position to either beat current consensus estimates for its
Q3 results or Q4 outlook, which we outlined in our preview report on 10/19. Nor do we
believe Twitter is in a position to announce a sale of the company. It could simply allow a
potential acquirer to make the necessary cuts once the deal closed if that was the case.
• Helping analysts out. Twitter also moved its earnings reporting time to Thursday before
the market open from after the market close on Thursday. This was due to conflicts with
several other large Internet companies reporting results and conducting conference calls at
the same time. We are sympathetic to scheduling earnings calls at staggered times relative
to peers and do not believe there is another reason the company moved the time earlier.

11:19 am
BE

I also note the conspiracy theory doing the rounds that Twitter's whole sale process was a bit of a false-flag operation.

BE

There was never an actual intention to sell. Instead, it was to establish in everyone's mind that there were no potential buyers, which would clear the air for the @Jack-led turnaround.

BE

That is, to be clear, a conspiracy theory to which we give no weight.

11:21 am
PM

hmm

PM

Maybe

BE

The bottom line here is that, while the fresh Disney stuff could plausibly be right, we've been told it isn't. The end.

11:22 am
undefined
PM

Lloyds down a tad on these Q3s

PM

More red ink from miss-selling, but all pretty much in the price

11:23 am
PM

Underlying it looks ok tho

PM

Except this:

PM

Common equity tier 1 (CET1) ratio of 14.1 per cent pre dividend

11:24 am
PM

Why would you highlight your CET ratio pre dividend?

BE

.................. pass.

PM

Anyway, Trader Gordon is a buyer

11:24 am
PM

He can talk thru the other numbers

PM

Underlying PBT of £1,912m was £25m (1%) below consensus. Within this, Net Interest Income was £4m (0%) ahead, with a robust NIM of 2.72%. Other Income was a £69m (4%) miss, costs a £36m (2%) beat and impairments a £12m (6%) miss. Below the line, the £1bn PPI top-up was as we expected, so reported PBT of £811m was £2m (0%) ahead of us. However, for us, the game-changer is a “surprise” boost to capital. The CET1 ratio rose 0.4pps QoQ to 13.4% which affords the option of an increased payout. BUY.

PM

As summarised in the table on page 2, revenues of £4.3bn were a £61m (1%) miss vs consensus as compiled by Inquiry Financial, entirely driven by another weak contribution from Other Income, with the Insurance Division continuing to disappoint in this regard. By contrast, with customer loans down by just £1bn QoQ to £452bn and a resilient NIM of 2.72% (vs 2.74% in Q2 2016), Net Interest Income was in line.

Costs of £2.2bn were a small (2%) beat vs consensus and impairments remained very low at £0.2bn, a £12m (6%) consensus miss. Guidance reaffirms an expectation that the full-year charge in 2016 will be below 20bps.

11:25 am
PM

Two key expected headwinds in Q3 were entirely as we thought. A £1.0bn top-up to Lloyds’ PPI charge, (cumulative charge £17.0bn), and a £1.2bn “swing” in the pension scheme, from a surplus of £430m at Q2 to a deficit of £740m at Q3 2016, taken together shaved 40bps off the CET1 capital ratio. Other things being equal, we expect the pension deficit to narrow in Q4 2016e.

PM

£17bn so far on PPI?!?!!?

PM

Didn't realise there were that many stupid people who said yes to loan insurance

11:26 am
PM

The issue which triggers clear upside to Lloyds’ dividend paying capacity is an (unexpected) 80bps benefit from reclassification of Lloyds’ £20bn gilt portfolio from “held to maturity” to “available for sale”. CET1 ratio is now 13.4% (consensus 12.9%). Lloyds has choices; it is within its gift to pay 3.5p for FY16.

Lloyds trades on 0.9x 2018e tNAV for RoTEs of 10/11% in 2017/18e and prospective dividend yields of 6/8/9% through 2016-18e. Buy rec and 68p TP reaffirmed. Only the finer detail of our forecasts are under review

PM

And Sandy Chen is a seller

PM

3Q16 looks a bit weak; statutory pbt of £811m is down 15% yoy, and even management’s underlying profit of £1.9bn (i.e. before a £1bn PPI top-up charge, £150m for packaged bank accounts etc) is down 3% yoy. Customer loans and deposits are flat versus 2Q16, and management’s version of net interest income is down 1% yoy (although statutory net income is down a lot more – from £9.0bn to £6.9bn for 9M16 on insurance gross-up and other volatility items).

Lloyds’ CET1 ratio of 13.4% (end-2Q16: 13.0%) is solid, but it’s important to note that there was a 20bp hit from a negative £1.2bn swing (from £430m surplus to £740m deficit) in the defined benefit pension schemes. Management say that this was more than offset by an 80bp boost by changing from held-to-maturity to available-for-sale accounting for the £20bn of gilts held in their liquidity portfolio – but whereas the change in gilts accounting was a one-off, we see the swing from net pension surplus to deficit as the beginning of a longer-term trend – that could lead to bigger hits to CET1.

Tangible BVPS per share of 54.9p as at end-3Q16 will probably nudge up in 4Q16, but the foreseeable 2016 dividend of 2.55p per share will probably nudge it down; leaving LLOY trading at a slight premium to tangible book, whereas all of its peers are trading at discounts to tangible book. Maintain Sell.

11:26 am
PM

Cenkos of course

PM

Chen quoting CET1 post dividend, of course

PM

(roddy1234 -- yes i am being unfair. I take it back)

11:28 am
PM

(Boncoeur -- i take it back. Being rash and rude. sorry)

BE

PPI confuses me a bit. The costs seem not to tally with the historic earnings bump.

BE

I'm also a bit nonplussed by the concept of Lloyds having underlying earnings, given it's not reported a clean set of earnings in .......... well, a decade basically.

11:29 am
BE

Have RBC, since we're here.

BE

Actually, RBC's screwed up its PDF. Have Deutsche instead.

BE

8% operating miss at the underlying level
Lloyds has reported 3Q16 results this morning. Operating performance is a
miss vs. our forecasts, driven by weaker income (NII a 2% miss, other income
an 8% miss), offset by a 1% beat on costs, and impairments inline. Overall this
represents an 8% miss at the underlying PBT level, and a 9% miss vs. Factset
consensus for 3Q16. Below the line, Lloyds reported a further £1bn for PPI (in
line with expectations) and £150m for other conduct provisions.
NIM at 269bps, we expect further pressure in 2017
NIM was 269bps for the quarter, guidance of 270bps for the full year remains.
Annualising the 3Q16 income performance shows that it is in line with
company consensus income for FY17e – but we expect further pressure to
follow in FY17 from the lower interest rate environment. Guidance for other
income is now £6bn for FY16, consensus is at c.£6.1bn for 2016-18.
Capital better at 13.4%...though benefiting from a reclassification of gilts
Elsewhere, capital was better at 13.4% and TNAV a 1% beat at 54.9p.
However, this beat vs. expectations (we had expected 12.9%) is a one-off, and
driven by a change in approach in the way they hold gilts in the liquidity
portfolio – from HTM to AFS, which aided capital by 80bps. Without this,
capital would have been a miss at 12.6%. Nevertheless, a beat is a beat – and
13.4% CET1 should provide Lloyds the headroom to pay the 3p dividend that
we and consensus expect for 2016 (requires 20-30bps capital generation in
4Q16), giving comfort for those focused on the dividend line.

11:31 am
BE

We would expect shares to be
weaker this morning on the operational miss, though the capital position
should reassure those who were concerned about the 2016 dividend.

undefined
PM

Oh look -- Tony Shiret really doesnt like B&M

11:31 am
PM

Nor do I

B&M European Value Retail SA (BME:LSE): Last: 237.10, down 1.7 (-0.71%), High: 239.70, Low: 236.40, Volume: 646.12k
PM

B&M
We don't like it

11:32 am
PM

The key issue here is whether we are looking at a sustainable longterm
growth story or whether the growth is being forced out of the
model by over-expansion, with growth masking a less robust
underlying proposition than investors currently believe. We have
modelled the performance characteristics of the latest larger store
openings and conclude that these are nearly 20% less sales
productive than the group’s existing UK stores, resulting in EBITDA
only being 10-15% higher than for existing stores despite 60%
greater space and roughly double the invested capital. Rent as a %
of sales appears to be nearly 7% against 4% for the existing stores.

PM

We have also tested B&M’s pricing credentials in Grocery – c.47% of
UK sales – and found that while it achieved a 16% lower price on
branded product, in our samples the lowest B&M price was 40%
more expensive than Aldi/Lidl and 35% more expensive than
grocery own-brand generally. B&M does not have own-brand in
grocery and has benefited in our view from the food retail majors’
pricing activity being focused on fresh food, which B&M hardly sells.

PM

In anticipation of the 15th November interims we would expect the
main interest on reporting to be the company’s evaluation of its
buying position relative to a much weakened sterling. Its nonGrocery
product (just over 50% of sales) is largely imported from
China. Clearly the LFL position in the UK will also be a significant
disclosure with last reported 1Q LFL benefiting from a change in
definition at headline level

11:00 am
PM

Welcome to ML

PM

We have reduced our estimates for March 2017 and 2018 by 6% and
18%. We now expect minimal eps progress for 2017/18E and
2018/19E. We retain our Sell rating and have reduced our Fair Value
by 21% to 190p reflecting principally DCF.

PM

Tony Shiret of Haitong, of course

11:33 am
PM

It's a long note. Will try and usual place it later

PM

But the proper grocers seem to be in favour today

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 244.00, up 3.8 (+1.58%), High: 245.10, Low: 240.90, Volume: 2.65m
11:34 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 213.75, up 3.6 (+1.71%), High: 213.85, Low: 209.60, Volume: 5.51m
PM

Is there a Goldman upgrade around?

BE

Well Sainsbury, I think, is on a Goldman non-upgrade.

11:35 am
BE

Upgrade to sell from conviction sell.

PM

Actually, GS a seller of Tesco, but they've raised their target price

BE

So still sell, but not with the conviction of previously.

11:35 am
PM

Ah right

BE

Sector wrap. Cover page incoming.

BE

Tesco/Morrison are +41%/+55% YTD, and trade
c.40% and c.25% above their 10-year avg. 12m
fwd EV/EBIT. On our analysis this means they are
pricing FY20 EBIT margins of c.4.2% (vs. mid-
point of Tesco’s guidance of 3.75%). This implies
they can achieve margins right at the top of global
peers. In the context of steep inflationary
pressures (UK Food input PPI greater than 10% in September)
we think valuations do not offer reward for the risk.

11:36 am
BE

Food is not very price elastic. But, when food CPI
goes above 2%, we see clear volume declines in
food consumption. For the Big 4 a further concern
is how high inflation precipitates behavioural
changes and drives consumers to the discounters.
The last time UK food CPI rose above 5% in 2011,
the discounters started to gain share, and
cumulatively gained 520 bp of market share by
end-2015. With the UK grocers growing LFL
volumes for the first time in over 5 yrs, we think
they will be unwilling to risk reversing this by
passing steep price rises to consumers.

BE

At a 25%-30% ex fuel gross margin, for every 1%
of input cost inflation that is not passed through to
consumers, a grocer will take a c.70 bp reduction
in operating margin. Recent ONS data shows food
CPI is lagging food PPI which suggests that some
input costs are not being passed through. We also
think the Asda threat should not be ignored. Asda
is net cash, EBIT margins are c.300 bp higher than
peers and it has lost over 90 bp of market share in
2016 YTD. Management has indicated that it could
invest in growth and therefore pressure the sector.

BE

With Tesco trading on a 2.2% FY18E FCF yield and
Morrison on 4%, we do not believe these stocks
are pricing in any margin risk from rising food
inflation. With 31% and 21% downside to our PTs,
respectively, we remain Sell rated. On Sainsbury,
we continue to forecast further margin declines in
its core grocery business and anticipate falling
EBIT at Argos as competition steps up and FX
hurts gross margins. However, with 20%
downside, less than for peers, we remove the
stock from the Conviction List, but remain Sell.

11:38 am
BE

Goldman's been a seller of Sainsbury and Tesco forever. As in, for about four years.

BE

I do like the Goldman protocol of adding recommendation histories in the smallprint.

BE

Here's the Tesco one.

11:39 am
BE

BE

And the Sainsbury one.

BE

11:40 am
BE

Fair to suggest, I think, that those calls haven't made many clients too rich.

undefined
PM

Andrew Perloff gone off on one again

11:41 am
PM

He's like our own version of the Tea Party

PM

One man Tea Party

BE

Oh, lord.

11:41 am
PM

Further to the comments made in the Chairman’s Statement included in the interim results announced on 27 September 2016, which contained information about how business rates might affect the Group, the majority of the new commercial rating values assessed on April 2015 values, but effective from April 2017 for England and Wales, have been announced together with the phasing arrangements due to be implemented.

As the Chairman, Andrew Perloff, suspected, his cynicism was well founded.

PM

Panther Securities of course

PM

As the Chairman, Andrew Perloff, suspected, his cynicism was well founded. From a brief research on a number of the new values for the Group’s properties, it is apparent that the values have been placed higher than justified by the April 2015 rental values. Andrew Perloff believes this is because the Valuation Officers have used what they call the “broad brush approach”. Translated this means not carrying out a thorough review of each property, but generalising and taking the highest denominator, as that suits government revenue raising purposes.

11:42 am
PM

Leaving aside the scandal of charging at full level business rates on vacant properties, the Directors believe this is a disgraceful, sneaky and unfair imposition. Larger retailers based out of the London area, will be hit hardest, particularly those in the northern parts of England.

It is the government’s stated wish to create a northern powerhouse. However, in the Directors’ view the Valuation Office’s approach to the phasing of the new commercial rating values is going to have the complete opposite effect.

BE

Andrew Perloff seems to be referring to himself in the third person here.

PM

hehehe, he is

11:42 am
PM

Andrew Perloff, Chairman of Panther, stated “If this is the best they can do on a rates revaluation then I doubt if they could create a profitable hot dog stall outside of Wembley Stadium on Cup Final Day, even if they issued themselves the only licence!

Panther Securities P L C (PNS:LSE): Last: 310.00, no change, Volume: 0.00
BE

Zing.

11:43 am
undefined
BE

And back to earth, I guess.

BE

Bit more sellside around to note, such as Diageo.

11:44 am
Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 2,215, up 11.5 (+0.52%), High: 2,219, Low: 2,210, Volume: 2.17m
BE

"The battleship is finally turning" says HSBC.

BE

Battle cruiser would've been better, given it's Cockney rhyming slang for pub, but I digress.

11:45 am
BE

The long-hoped for cultural change looks to have arrived and we turn
bullish after an extended period of caution
Management appears to be executing better than at any time in recent
memory, easing our concerns about the future
Upgrade to Buy from Hold, raise target price c11% to 2,600p

BE

Anthony Bucalo is the analyst here.

BE

More than just a post-Brexit vote rally: Diageo historically has been
known as a company that has struggled to meet expectations. Our valuation
and rating of the stock has typically priced in some scepticism, leading
us to be more bearish than many.

However, after a year of extended conversations with managers across the
company, we think Diageo's often criticised corporate culture is finally
evolving in the direction long hoped for by the market. This gives us
optimism that management is executing more efficiently than at any time in
recent memory; we are, in effect, giving the benefit of the doubt to a
management team that is affecting change in a meaningful and constructive
way.

11:46 am
BE

What corporate culture's that? I guess they still have an in-house pub in the Oxford Street office.

BE

Thus we are upgrading Diageo shares to Buy from Hold for two reasons.
First, operationally we believe Diageo is: (i) focused on meaningful cost
control, (2) benefitting from a booming and well-resourced Reserve
portfolio push and (3) stoking solid local growth stories. All of these we
believe will continue to drive the stock from here post the Brexit vote
rally.

Second, due to Diageo's high operational exposure to the US and the
Eurozone, the recent update to HSBC's global cost of equity estimates has
an immediate positive impact on our DCF valuation. We lower our WACC by
30bps to 6.3% from 6.6%, resulting in a new target price of 2,600p, an
increase of c11% from 2,350p previously.

BE

Trading at a P/E of 21.1x versus our calendar 2017e EPS of 103.62p, the
stock remains at a 5% discount to the group average of 22.5x, making it an
attractive option versus expensive peers.
